p: Taking into account that the control voles remained asymptomatic, one can conclude that these neurobehavioral changes in infected voles were likely a consequence of BDV infection. However, based on sample size, these findings are not supported statistically (Mid-P exact, p = 0.055). Nonetheless, they are consistent with findings in neonatally BDV-infected laboratory mice and rats [15], [50], [58], which are considered to be a consequence of neurotransmitter imbalance [59]. Indeed, BDV seems to be able to alter and impair the functions of nerve cells through interference with the protein kinase C –dependent signaling by the P protein, affecting the stimulus-induced synaptic plasticity [60], [61]. Nevertheless, most voles in this study remained asymptomatic, and those symptoms observed did not significantly correlate with BDV infection status.
